subject: RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy
msgSnippet: J.B wrote:  ... David, for putting this example in 	the spotlight. ... walker, rather than a mock ... implemented to hardcode specified ... data, then,
messageBody:
J.B wrote:

<snip/>

> This is where I disagree with the use of mocks. I have to thank you,
David, for putting this example in > the spotlight.

> The second test may be better if it depends on the data from the classpath
walker, rather than a mock
> classpath walker. Presumably the mock classpath walker will be
implemented to hardcode specified
> classpath walking data, anyway. I propose to extract the classpath walking
data, then, and pass it to
> the second object, rather than mocking a classpath walker.

J.B. I really have to thank you for not using this as an opportunity to
distract. Right after I sent this I feared I'd be told "integration not
unit" and have the whole thread thrown out (or get side tracked) for that
one thought. That would be a shame on one example.

That all said, I half wonder if you are being tongue in check or
something -- seriously -- because if you aren't joking, you said "this test
is best if it depends upon that test". Further, you said use a side effect
(saved result) of one test for the next. [If you are saying store it in a
file, check that file in and test against it, then aren't we risking that
the output changes and the test isn't truly valid?] This all confuses me,
since it seems to go against so much of what you said.

Being more practical than purist I just need to know that my code works, I
don't care too much what is an internal-to-my-code-integration test, or not.
As such, I concur with what you are saying -- but I'd have my second test
use the class in the first, not us stored results or mock objects. I need to
know that the solution I provide works as a unit (irrespective of user
input/others) that is my goal for using junit. If not we could never junit
anything above the JDK 'cos we'd be doing "integration" test.

So, do we have a valuable concept of a dependency? If this is the best way
for me, the user, is to test my code -- ought I be able to want it to stop
if the walker failed?

regards,

Adam
